xxl.core.indexStructures

Class Separator

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.indexStructures.Separator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cloneable, Comparable, Descriptor
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BooleanSeparator, BPlusTree.KeyRange, ByteSeparator, DateSeparator, DoubleSeparator, FloatSeparator, HilbertRTree.ORSeparator, IntegerSeparator, IntSeparator, LongSeparator, LongSeparator, MVBTree.LifeSpanSeparator, MVBTree.MVSeparator, ShortSeparator, StringSeparator, TimeSeparator, TimestampSeparator, TupleSeparator

    public abstract class Separator
extends Object
implements Descriptor, Comparable
    This class describes the known separtors of the B+ tree. A Separtor is a simple key (for example an Integer). The Separator of a query is a closed intervall [min, max]. With the contructors of the class Separator Separators of every type can be created. This class uses the interface Comparable as a key class. Since the interface Comparable does not support the method clone() we have to let clone() abstract here. To use this class you only have to extend it to a concret class and implement the abstract method clone(). For Example: 
    
                        public class IntSeparator extends BPlusTree.Separator {
                                                        
                                public IntSeparator(Integer key) {
                                        super(key);
                                } 
                                
                                        public Object clone() {
                                                return new IntSeparator(new Integer(((Integer)sepValue).intValue()));
                                        }
                        }
    See Also:
    Descriptor, Comparable

      • isRightOf

        public boolean isRightOf(Comparable key)
        Checks whether a given key has to be on the left or right side of this Separator.
        Parameters:
        key - the key whose position has to be determined
        Returns:
        false if this Separator is definite and its separation value is smaller than the given key, true otherwise

      • isDefinite

        public boolean isDefinite()
        Checks whether the separation value of this Separator is definite (not null).
        Returns:
        true if the separation value is not null, false otherwise.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Object sep)
        Compares the current Separator with another one by using the default Comparator of this class.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable
        Parameters:
        sep - separator to compare to
        Returns:
        a integer value which indicates how the both Separators lie to each other. The result is as follows:
        • 0 if both Separators are indefinite or both are definite and the separation values are equals.
        • -1 if only the current Separator is indefinite or both are definite and the separation value of the current Separator is smaller than the separation value of the given one.
        • 1 if only the given Separator is indefinite or both are definite and the separation value of the current Separator is bigger than the separation value of the given one.
          See Also:
          DEFAULT_COMPARATOR

        • union

          public void union(Descriptor descriptor)
          Computes the union of this and a given Separator. It sets the separation value of the current Separator to the minimum of both separation values.
          Specified by:
          union in interface Descriptor
          Parameters:
          descriptor - has to be an instance of the class Separator
